speaker: Mr Williams (Tangney
theText: Attomey-General and Minister for Justice) (11.43) a.m.), in3852 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 15 May 1997 committed a relevant offence, that is, the same standard as for arrest. However, if a person is in lawful custody, non-intimate procedures may be carried out by appropriately qualified persons, as ordered by a senior constable. Further safeguards include: time limits for conducting procedures; the right to contact a lawyer and to communicate with him or her in private wherever possible; the right of certain suspects to interview friends; the right to an interpreter when necessary; tape recording of requests to consent and the conduct of procedures, and the provision of full information about the relevant procedure. Most importantly, the bill includes a legislative barrier to the admissibility of evidence which is obtained from forensic procedures which are carried out in breach of the legislation. All procedures must be carried out by appropriately qualified persons. There is a right to have a medical practitioner of choice present during most procedures, and a medical practitioner of the same sex if practicable. There are limitations on the numbers of constables that may be present during the carrying out of a forensic procedure and restriction on the presence of opposite sex constables to cases of necessity. There are also comprehensive requirements for the destruction of forensic material after a conviction is secured or charges dropped. The government is grateful for what might be described as the lack of opposition by the opposition to the bill, although the member for Banks did indicate that the opposition proposed to monitor the debate in order to see whether the bill could be improved during its passage through parliament. That is, of course, legitimate. It would help that if any deficiencies, or alleged deficiencies, are identified, they are made known to us so that the issue can be addressed and an appropriate answer can be given if there is one. The member for Banks raised the issue of certain recommendations of the Senate Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs not being accepted by the government. Among the Senate committee recommendations which were not taken up are some I will mention. Recommendation 1 limits the operation of the bill to offences with a maximum penalty of five years or more. This has not been adopted. The relevant offences tend to have maximum penalties of two to five years, being offences against the person in the main. The most useful application of the procedures would be excluded if it were limited to those with a penalty of five years or more. Reference is made to dental impressions. I think the member for Banks acknowledged that there had been an advance in technology since the original bill was prepared. Evidence before the committee, I am advised, was in fact outdated and came from the mid-1980s. The government has received up-to-date expert advice, which indicates that such evidence, using modem techniques, is both reliable and useful. The third recommendation was that the examination of female breasts should only be in relation to alleged offences of over five years maximum penalty. Similar arguments apply to that as I offered in relation to the non-adoption of the first recommendation. In certain crimes, especially violent or sexual crimes, evidence may be found on any part of the body, and the government saw no more reason to exclude the female breast area, subject to appropriate safeguards, than any other area of the body. Recommendation 9 was to the effect that the suspect definition be confined to persons a constable believes, rather than suspects, on reasonable grounds to have committed a relevant offence. That has not been picked up. That would have had the effect of excluding many people from the protections of the bill. The police could still seek their consent for procedures, Thursday, 15 May 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 3853 as they can for non-suspects, but the protections in the bill would not apply. Several other recommendations, which were not fully accepted, were in fact accepted in part or in spirit or implemented in a somewhat different way. Greater detail on these matters can be found in the government's formal response to the committee's recommendations. The member for Dickson expressed some concern about aspects of the bill relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, particularly the possibly patronising effect or appearance of provisions treating Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders as disadvantaged. He pointed out that this would be the case no matter how well educated or socially competent they may be. He gave an example in relation to the application of the lower two-hour time limit for the procedures in relation to those people. That provision and similar provisions in part 1C of the Crimes Act, relating to pre-charge investigation periods, were inserted following full consultation with Aboriginal organisations and also result from recommendations of the Senate committee. The government was aware of and concerned about the possibly patronising connotations. But those, it appears, were outweighed by the benefits of the provision in the eyes of the affected groups consulted. The member for Maribyrnong expressed some reservations about the reliability of DNA evidence and he raised some questions about databases. The bill does not require a court to admit any forensic evidence and it does not require a jury to give forensic evidence any particular weight. It merely allows forensic evidence to be obtained and leaves the question of admissibility and the question of weight to the judge and to the jury as appropriate. Recent criticisms of DNA evidence are an understandable reaction to the widely held but inaccurate view that DNA matching can always conclusively determine guilt or innocence. In fact, the value of DNA evidence varies from case to case, depending on the quality of the sample at the crime scene, the nature of the tests performed and the distinctiveness of the DNA in question. In some cases DNA evidence will be of little value; in others, it may show a high probability that DNA found at a crime scene is the suspect's DNA. The defence can conduct its own analysis of the defendant's DNA. If it is able to create real uncertainty as to the reliability of DNA evidence on which the prosecution relies, a jury would be unable to find the defendant guilty beyond reasonable doubt. The 1996 Esteal Interim report on the establishment of a national convicted offender database considered comprehensively the international evidence now available in this area and concluded that it is a powerful tool in law enforcement. It has the potential to reduce costs by eliminating suspects at an early stage and focusing the investigation to allow optimal use of investigation resources. Dr Esteal's final report is due to be presented to the Australasian Police Ministers Council meeting in July this year. In relation to databases, the bill does not establish any database, nor does it require any law enforcement agency to create a database, but it does recognise two kinds of existing databases. The first are identification databases, such as fingerprint databases, which contain a description of certain forensic material and the identity of the person from whom it was obtained. This allows police to match forensic material found at the scene of a crime against material in the database to identify suspects. However, as soon as forensic material is required to be destroyed, all information about that material must be removed from the identification database. All other material will be destroyed if proceedings have been unduly delayed, if the suspect is not 3854 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 15 May 1997 convicted or if evidence arising out of the procedure is held to be inadmissible because there was a breach of the bill's requirements. The other type of database that the bill recognises has a quite different purpose. Information about forensic material taken in accordance with the bill may be entered in a statistical database, but only in a form that cannot be used to identify any person. A statistical database of forensic material is a necessity. Much forensic evidence involves comparison with a large sample group. For example, the more DNA records the police have, the more accurately they can state the probability of two samples of DNA having come from the same source. A couple of other matters were raised that I think warrant comment, not because they were critical, but in a sense because they were supportive and raised issues of some significance. In the course of raising questions as to the quality of some evidence, in particular DNA evidence, the member for Maribymong suggested that science should not dominate the process. I think what I have said in relation to DNA evidence in particular should answer that, in that at the broad level science does not under the rules of evidence dominate the process. AndI do not think competent lawyers or courts will allow it to do so. The question of cost does arise, but that is really outside the terms of reference of this particular bill and no doubt will be a matter addressed in other forums, in particular those dealing with legal aid. The member for Lindsay perhaps adopted a slightly different approach to some issues than other speakers. That might not be surprising, given that all the other speakers were male and the member for Lindsay is female. The principle that there should be certainty of identification, a high level of skill in investigation and therefore the probability of greater conviction is important in offering the community both assurance of protection and the fact of protection. Women in particular have a perception that there are great risks in the community. Statistically those risks are in fact quite slight and the perception is of a greater risk than there really is. This is well documented by work done by the Australian Institute of Criminology. The member for Maribymong referred to the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, the National Police and Research Institute and the Institute of Forensic Science and made the point that there is cooperation between different law enforcement agencies and, in particular, police forces, through these cooperative bodies. That is a very important point to be made. I think we could also add there that the Institute of Criminology, with its Criminology Research Council, similarly operates, in effect, as a cooperative body. There is a great deal of cooperation between the different law enforcement agencies. The existence of the ABCI, for example, enables the possible setting up-to give another example--of a paedophile database. The existence of the National Exchange of Police Information, another cooperative body, was crucial in setting up appropriate uniform procedures for registration and licensing of firearms under the uniform gun laws that have been introduced in the last 12 months. The uniformity of law that would arise if each jurisdiction adopts a bill based on this model, a model developed by the Model Criminal Code Officers Committee, would be undoubted, a point emphasised by the member for Lindsay. The passage of this bill through this parliament will constitute a milestone in moving towards that target. I will hand up a replacement explanatory memorandum. This replaces the original one which Was found to contain some minor errors, such as numbering errors, affecting a few sections, inaccuracies in describing the effect of two provisions and some typographical errors. I commend the bill to the House. Thursday, 15 May 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 3855 Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Bill-by leave-reported to the House without amendments. Second Reading Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Mr Miles: That the bill be now read a second time. upon which Mr Latham moved by way of amendment: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House: (1) expresses concern at the failure of the Howard Government, after 12 months in office, to respond to the recommendations of the report of the Joint Select Committee into Certain Family Law Issues entitled 'Child Support Scheme: An Examination of the Operation and Effectiveness of the Scheme'; (2) believes the Government should be concerned about the well-being and welfare of all families: whether they be intact families, separated families, single parent families or serial families; (3) notes with concern the failure to implement some of the report's recommendations has caused parents and their children to suffer needless hardship; (4) believes that there is important and urgent need to improve and strengthen the Child Support Scheme; and (5) considers that much time has been lost and therefore the Government should respond to the recommendations of the report concerned with changing the child support formula as soon as possible and introduce legislation within six months to this effect". by their very nature complex and technical, and they deal with very emotionally charged issues. The task of the Child Support Agency is, of course, an enormous one. It has responsibility for most areas of child support, from regulation to assessment, to collection of child support and payment to the custodial parents. It must also assess and adjudicate on any request for a variation of child support liability, based either on an estimate of changed circumstances or on any other review grounds contained within the act. There have been a number of problems with the Child Support Act, many of which were identified in the 1994 report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. Of course, those of us working in our electorate offices have people coming in daily talking to us about the human consequences of the problems of dealing in this highly vexed area and the act as it now stands. The amendments contained in the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 1996, which is before the committee today, are designed to ensure that the child support system continues to evolve to meet its objectives in the future as best it can. They represent a number of common sense administrative changes which were flagged by the joint select committee that I have just referred to. In particular, the Child Support Act was introduced to address the need for a better, more informed system of ensuring that a parent's child support and child maintenance obligations are assessed accurately and met regularly. The underlying principle of the child support system
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mrs Stone (Murray) (12.13 P.m.)
theText: The Child Support Act and associated regulations are3856 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 15 May 1997 is that both parents, custodial and non-custodial, have a joint obligation to provide for the care and upkeep of their children as best they can. When the child support legislation was first introduced, the stated objectives of the cabinet subcommittee on maintenance and child support were that: non-custodial parents share in the cost of supporting their children according to their capacity to pay; adequate support is available to all children not living with both parents; Commonwealth expenditure is limited to the minimum necessary for ensuring that those needs are met; work incentives to participate in the labour force are not impaired; and the overall arrangements are non-intrusive to personal privacy and are simple, flexible and efficient. These principles remain the guiding force in the government's consideration of the child support scheme and any reforms that are necessary. In particular, the final objective is addressed by these amendments being debated today. The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 contains three main changes. These changes are to the estimates provisions, the employer withholding provisions and the treatment of child support liabilities by the Family Court. The bill also includes consequential changes to child support legislation to reflect changes made in the Social Security Act 1991, the Family Law Act 1975 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. These changes are aimed at increasing flexibility for the Child Support Agency and for the parents involved, reducing the level of intrusiveness, and improving certainty and the clarity of the law. Currently, where the Child Support Agency is involved in the assessment of child support, it calculates the amount to be paid based on the non-custodial parent's income from two years ago. This figure is offset against the income of the custodial parent once that income reaches a certain threshold. One of the difficulties with this situation is that a person's economic and employment circumstances can change dramatically within a two-year period. People may find themselves in a situation where the amount of child support that they are paying is much higher than if they were assessed on their current income--or, alternatively, it could be much lower. Currently, to address this problem, the child support system incorporates an estimate procedure. Either parent can apply for a variation of child support payments if they believe that their income in the current year will vary by more than 15 per cent. The reassessment is then backdated to the end of the previous financial year. This process is fraught with practical difficulties. It often means that the custodial parent has to refund to the non-custodial parent money that they have already spent on the care and upkeep of their children. It could have been spent on education, clothing, food, sporting activities or housing. It also may mean that the parent paying child support has to repay much of the amount which would be refunded later in the year when they may not be in a position to do so. So it is very often a lose-lose situation, and it affects not just the parents, but the children. It may cause tensions and stress, as well as economic hardship. The provisions contained in the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 1996 will amend the effect of an income estimate election to make it less likely that a person receiving child support will be asked to repay amounts in the future, and they will make the effect of an income estimate election a much more accurate reflection of a paying parent's capacity to pay. Revised assessments, on the basis of an estimate, will apply only from the date that the estimate is lodged. These amendments allow that a custodial parent will not have to refund money that they have already received but, rather, any overpayment will reduce the amount Thursday, 15 May 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 3857 that the non-custodial parent is required to pay for the remainder of the year. The only exception to this would be when the amount payable, after the readjustment, is actually lower than the amount that has already been paid. Another important change is that non-custodial parents, when unemployed for part of the year, will not have to pay child support. The revised income estimate will be used by the Child Support Agency to reassess the amount of child support payable for that year. These measures, it is important to note, do not actually change the amount of child support that a person is liable to pay. They simply change the way in which any reassessments affect the timing of liabilities and ensure they reflect the person's ability to meet their child support obligations at any given time. These changes therefore address one of the main disadvantages for custodial parents who are having to repay child support that they have received and spent in good faith. It is a significant change for custodial parents, particularly those who may have a variable income. Such amendments are of particular importance for many people in my electorate where we have numbers employed as seasonal workers. It is very difficult for seasonal workers in the food producing, fruit picking and transport sector-which is very subject to seasonality-to accurately forecast what their income will be from one year to the next. Seasonal workers are often given short notice as to extension of their employment-extra overtime in the factory, some night work. Due to the uncharacteristically good season, they might find themselves with many more weeks of work than they had expected, at a higher pay. Many of these people are anxious to meet their child support obligations, as are all parents. Ensuring that they do not accumulate large arrears debts is also a major concern for them. Under the current system, if they lodge an estimate at the time their income is about to increase, the increased amount of child support is backdated to the end of the financial year. This can then be a disincentive for additional work. While parents are prepared to pay additional child support when their circumstances improve, being hit immediately with an arrears debt and even further increased payments is often unfair, and is certainly felt as unfair. to do the right thing, especially in my area. The amendments to ensure that estimates only operate from the date they are lodged will help to alleviate their situation and ensure that the child support assessments reflect the non-custodial parent's current financial position. The Child Support Agency can collect child support in a number of ways. Another option for collection is that the paying parent pays the amount directly to the Child Support Agency. There is also the possibility for parents to reach a private arrangement between themselves as to the amount and payment of child support. In these cases, the support agency will not intervene unless the custodial parent has applied for a means tested social security benefit, for example, a supporting mother's pension or disability support pension. In these cases, the Child Support Agency must make a child support assessment. The evidence given to the 1994 Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues found that approximately one-third of separated parents are clients of the Child Support Agency, while the rest have made private child support agreements. The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 1996 seeks to amend the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 to allow a payer of child support to make payments directly to the child support registrar in certain circumstances. Obviously, the main criteria will be that the registrar is

speaker: Mrs Stone
theText: Some parents indeed! Some do not, but many parents are very concerned3858 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 15 May 1997 satisfied that the person will meet their child support obligations. These are simple administrative measures, but they have some very important effects. At present, the Child Support Agency is often seen as invading the privacy of a noncustodial parent when it takes employer withholding action. Even though that parent might have the very best intentions towards their family, they still feel a great sense of being accused of wrongdoing and wrong intent. These changes will reduce the intrusive nature of the child support collection process in many cases. The changes also provide greater flexibility in the way the child support payments are collected, which we expect will substantially reduce administrative costs. The changes will also reduce the compliance costs placed on employers who are directed to withhold child support payments, as more people will now be allowed to pay directly to the Child Support Agency if these amendments are passed. Such changes are especially important given the government's commitment to reducing paperwork and the costs for small businesses. While it may be relatively easy for large employers to meet their withholding obligations under the child support system, it is a further burden on small employers, especially when in many cases it is not necessary for them to be involved at all. This is particularly a problem where you have family members-perhaps the family of the custodial parent-employing the non-custodial parent. Matters of privacy can become very important. In having to be directly involved in maintenance payments, there can be a lot of inter-family stress. It is important to ensure that children are never disadvantaged in the event that child support is not paid on time, or at all. The child support register will maintain the primary responsibility to ensure the collection of child support in a timely manner. This, of course, is as it should be. The amendments provide for strict safeguards in the event of default. If a person elects to pay directly to the Child Support Agency and then defaults in payment, there are a number of important safeguards in place which are to ensure that the children are not disadvantaged by the failure of non-custodial parents to meet their child support obligations. Ifa person does default, the CSA can require that child support be withheld by a person's employer in the future and a payer will not be able to make another election for direct payment for six months. In most cases, payers who default after choosing to pay directly to the registrar, will have strictly limited future access to this provision. Where a person applies for direct payment to the registrar and this application is refused-presumably on the basis of a history of defaultthis person will not be able to apply for direct payment again for two months. These amendments reflect recommendations 55 and 57 of the joint select committee report and remove the situation where, under section 43 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act, the child support registrar is required, as far as practicable, to collect child support from the wages of the employed, liable parents. I understand that the practice of the Child Support Agency, in compliance with this legislation, is that, as soon as they become, or are made aware, of the employer of a noncustodial parent, they take action to commence employer withholding. Often the first notification that the person has that their salary is being withheld to meet their child support obligations is when they receive a reduced pay packet, or their employer advises them of the notice that they have received to make these deductions. That is hardly fair and, as I said Thursday, 15 May 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 3859 before, can lead to very substantially exacerbated tensions between the parents of the child. In this case, of course, the child suffers as much as the parents. Evidence presented by the Child Support Agency to the joint select committee indicated that there had been an improved level of voluntary compliance. For example, it was reported that 56 per cent of all child support liabilities registered under the scheme were paid on time and that almost half of these were paid without the use of automatic withholding. It is important that parents are given the opportunity, where appropriate, to pay their child support voluntarily, and these amendments help to make that happen. This bill will also amend the Family Law Act. The amendments will mean that the court can take child support liability into account when ruling on property and spousal maintenance issues, even where a child support assessment has not been issued. This will help to ensure that property settlements more accurately reflect the true situation of both the parties and take into account the impact that future child support liabilities may have upon the non-custodial parent's financial situation. It is clearly desirable in family law matters that parties reach agreement on pivotal issues such as child support. However, the current arrangements mean that parties must apply for a child support assessment-even where they wish to make private arrangements-before the court can take into account those commitments when making orders regarding property or spousal maintenance. These amendments reflect the position that all parents should be treated in the same manner, and we support that strongly. I support the changes proposed today as practical and sensible amendments to the child support legislation. The business of taking care of children in a situation of separated parents is one that the state must overview-in this case the nation-but we must also give parents the greatest possible chance to continue to live in harmony so that their harmonious relationships offer the best possible chance of parenting to their children. In particular, I should also add that we believe that these amendments are supported by both sides of the House and we believe that they have had a strong investigation by both parties in previous times as joint select committees have worked through the issues. In particular, these amendments give parents dignity and a greater chance to continue cooperative relationships. I therefore commend the bill to the Main Committee. indicated, there are few areas of government responsibility that raise emotions more than matters pertaining to family law. Certainly, since its introduction, the Child Support Act has created a lot of angst within the Australian community. It is an act that is in need of reform, there is no doubt about that. Before going on to those matters, however, I think it is important to recognise that the system we have today is much better than the system we had previously. The introduction of the Child Support Act was probably the biggest shake-up in terms of family law in this country since the introduction of the Family Law Act of 1975. It was an important initiative, one which has delivered to this country a much better system than we had previously. It addressed the high cost of applying for maintenance before the courts in this country. We must remember that, before the introduction of the scheme, only about 26 per cent of sole parents were in receipt of some form of maintenance from the non-custodial parent. It addressed the problem of the lack of indexing of the commitments of non-custodial parents as determined by courts of the land.

speaker: Mr Fitzgibbon (Hunter) 02.30 P.m.)
theText: As the member for Murray( Mrs Stone) has3860 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 15 May 1997 It overcame the difficulties inherent in enforcing court orders. We can now rely upon the tax system and the powers of the Child Support Agency to ensure that non-custodial parents in this country make their contribution, quite rightly, to the children they have fathered or mothered. The previous situation was unacceptable. We had a situation in this country where it was the taxpayer generally, through the provision of the sole parents pension, that was carrying the maximum weight of the cost of raising these children, rather than the responsibility being sheeted home to the person responsible for fathering or mothering the child, that person no longer having contact. The scheme was a very important initiative and I think that, as a matter of principle, it enjoys the support of both sides of this parliament. But it is desperately in need of reform. That is why today I am supporting in this place the amendments put forward by the member for Werriwa( Mr Latham). This bill, while I welcome its initiatives and while I am happy to say that it will go some way towards addressing some of the inadequacies of the scheme, does not go far enough. It fails rather poorly to pick up the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. I know that a number of those on the other side will say that the former Labor government failed to put them into practice, but we were getting there. Many of them were introduced or picked up, and the reform process was continuing. I always remind myself, as a member of this place, to remember that one day-fingers crossed-I may be in government. I remind myself to be very careful about the things I say in this place, because they do have a habit of coming back to bite us. In my first 12 months in this place I have watched with great interest the transformation of many of those on the other side as they have felt their way into government. The Child Support Agency was a great ogre in the eyes of many on the other side when they were in opposition. Now, 14 months into this government, what we see is this Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 1996, which does very little indeed to address the inadequacies of the system. I point that out to members on the other side with some great pleasure. Government members interjecting Mr Deputy Speaker, that the success of the scheme was originally underestimated. No-one ever dreamed that the success of the child support scheme would be so large. It was originally under-administered; not enough money was going into the scheme to enable those very hard working members of that area of government to properly administer the scheme. That is slowly being addressed. The former Labor government picked up many of the recommendations of the joint select committee, and that process was ongoing. Having heard the whining from the other side when they were in opposition, this is their attempt at fixing up the child support scheme. They are making a few very minor changes which I welcome, as I said, but they are going to do very little to address the problems faced by both custodial and non-custodial parents in this country. I note that, very subtly, many of them have raised concerns that they have on a wider basis. They have all given examples of how they continue to experience problems with the system, particularly with respect to non-custodial parents, and yet their bill before the House today does very little to address those problems-and there are plenty of problems. It is very dangerous for a male member of this place to do so, but I have seen too many cases where non-custodial males are being absolutely devastated by this scheme-not to say

speaker: Mr Fitzgibbon
theText: My team introduced the scheme in the first place. You Will remember,Thursday, 15 May 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 3861 that I think the pendulum has swung too far the other way. It was the case that, prior to the introduction of the scheme, the non-custodial males were getting away with murder. They were being carried by the Australian taxpayer. Now, instead of the pendulum swinging back to the centre, I think it has gone a little too far the other way. Now there are too many male, noncustodial parents out there with problems-and, indeed, female, non-custodial parents as well. AlthoughI have not come across them, I am sure they are out there. I know how dangerous it is to say this because I know that whenever someone prefaces a racial remark by saying, 'But, let me say, I am not a racist,' I immediately come to the conclusion that they are. My preface in signalling my concerns about non-custodial parents is not going to help me much, but I felt an obligation to say it. I also feel an obligation to say that the system is acting as a disincentive to many workers because, over time, it is not a proposition to them anymore; it is not worth their while. The system is leaving many non-custodial parents with no opportunity to start again. It is leaving them without the financial means to start life again. And, of course, those financial strains also flow on to strains on the relationship with their second partners and, subsequently, this can lead to a second breakdown and another child support liability-and it goes on and on. For the non-custodial parent, the whole thing can be disastrous. The scheme does not take into account a child's income. Theoretically, if I separated from my wife, I could have a 17-year-old child earning $80,000 a year and still have a liability to my ex-wife. It does not take into account the income of the new partner of the custodial parent: if I had an ex-wife, she could be living with or be remarried to someone earning $1 million a year and yet my liability to my children would not change. Obviously, in those situations, my commitment should remain. I should always have a liability to my children-and I am pretty confident that most non-custodial parents believe they should have, too-but common sense must prevail. With the introduction of the actual means test used to assess one's eligibility for Austudy, we now take into account much more the direct income stream of the parents involved. We look at a few other functions as well, including their expenditure patterns and other liabilities they might have as a family. It would make a lot of sense to apply those same principles to the child support legislation because, for example, it does not now take into account the cost incurred by the non-custodial parent at those times when he or she enjoys the company of the children. When you are estranged from your children, you want to give them the very best during those short periods you have with them. You want to treat them; you want to take them out; you want to take them to the show, and you want to buy them good things. Under the child support scheme, your liability does not take into account the cost involved. SoI think there is some scope for some big changes there. Probably the more important point to make is that we in this place should be talking about family law generally rather than restricting ourselves to amendments to the child support scheme. For example-just to quote one case-I have a very distressed constituent who has a child support liability to, I think, six children. He is a coal miner and therefore enjoys a pretty reasonable income. But his liability to child support is very large, as you can imagine. He is not complaining about that; he pays almost happily. What he is concerned about is the welfare of his children. When the custody was being determined, while his ex-wife enjoyed the benefits of the support of legal aid, he did not. He was forced to represent himself before the Family Court and his child support liability was so large that he was left with no money 3862 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 15 May 1997 with which to engage a solicitor. In any case, because he was the male in the relationship, his chances of success in terms of his attempts to gain custody of the children were minuscule. The ex-wife was granted custody and now he has an ongoing concern about the welfare of those children. We all have cases come into our office regularly, and often they are very sad cases. But we always treat them very carefully because we know that there are always two sides of the story. But over time, I have done the dangerous thing and come to acceptof advice. It is so true. But I have come to lean towards the man's side of the story. I have become concerned about the children as well, because of some of the incidences that he relates to me. As a member of parliament, I am in no place to make a judgment about these matters and, indeed, the Department of Community Services in New South Wales is equally concerned. Of course, they cannot move until the situation is absolutely drastic. So where does my constituent tum? He cannot go back to the courts to appeal the custody decision because he has no money, mainly because of his child support liability. So he is forced to sit back and wear the current Family Law Act and many of the inequities contained within it. So we cannot just take the child support legislation on its own and pretend that we are going to seriously address the family law issues facing this nation. This is a start and I welcome it. As I said, the recommendations contained within it are helpful and will address many of the inequities, particularly those that are introduced when an overpayment, or an underpayment, is raised. I think this is a much more sensible way of addressing those problems. But, as the member for Werriwa points out in his amendment, this bill reflects the absolute lack of commitment on the part of the government to address the real issues contained within the child support legislation. It displays absolutely their unwillingness, now that they are in government, to address the real issues in terms of family law and, while we are not denying the bill a second reading, of course, I think that it is important to highlight that fact. I commend the amendments of the member for Werriwa to the House. in the electorate of Dunkley, across all income ranges and family types. In every suburb throughout the electorate people are experiencing contact with the Child Support Agency. The marriage and relationship education courses in Frankston and other Peninsula locations are offering people improved encouragement so that they do not find themselves in the situation of having to separate from their children and from their partners, and basically to help them get on with the rest of their lives. The Child Support Agency is an important part of the institutional framework that seeks to ensure that the children of discontinued relationships continue to be cared for and develop with the support of both parents, where their parents move on to pursue separate lives. WhatI like about this child support legislation is that it seeks to further humanise this institutional framework with changes that ensure that the legal and administrative arrangements can take account of real people's lives and their individual circumstances. The bill before this committee will not be the last word on changes to the child support scheme or family law. speaker: Mr Billson (Dunkley) (12.45 P.m.)
theText: The Child Support Agency has at least 2,500 clientsThursday, 15 May 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 3863 same report that the predecessors, the former Labor government, found too difficult to deal with, but who are now very keen in chanting from their stalls what this government should do about it. It is interesting to look at some of the remarks members opposite are making, and particularly the amendments offered by the member for Werriwa( Mr Latham). Again, there was very little in the way of constructive contribution to addressing these significant problems but more evidence that Labor is happy to sit back, chant from the sidelines, but leave it to the coalition parties to make some useful changes to this situation. As a member elected in 1996, I am well aware that this inquiry recei ved 6,197 submissions, the highest ever for any parliamentary committee in our country. I remind the House that noncustodial parents made 3,292 submissions, or 53 per cent of the submissions, and custodial parents 32 per cent. Further changes are required to respond fairly and effectively to the many issues raised during the inquiry and since then, and I am committed to pursuing them. The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 is a start. Today's bill addresses three areas. It aims to make income estimate elections notified by parents paying child support a more accurate reflection of their ability to pay. So when a payer's income drops more than 15 per cent, and they lodge an income election, their future liability will be reduced, rather than the complicated and annoying system that operates at present. This will lessen the chances of parents who receive child support already spending the money but not being aware that the paying parents income election has changed the amount of moneys effectively due. Fewer payees will be required to repay overpaid amounts of child support, and payers who are unemployed for part of the year will not be required to pay child support. The child support system will be better able to accommodate changing circumstances of the non-custodial parents. As I was saying, this change will help to avoid the hardship created when the agency seeks to recover payments from custodial parents who may well have already spent the money on raising the children. Secondly, the bill seeks to reduce the big brother nature of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 where it is unnecessary. The amendment allows child support payers with a good record to make payments directly to registrars rather than going through employers. Importantly, a person must have a good payment record before he or she can make payments in this way. If a default occurs, payers will not be able to remit moneys directly to the registrar for another six months. In the meantime, they will have to revert to garnishee orders through their employer as a penalty. Finally, the Family Law Act is to be amended to enable people voluntarily paying child support to have that taken into account when the Family Court is making a property or spouse maintenance order. No longer will court orders fail to reflect the true circumstances of a person already paying child support. This measure will remove the current disincentive for parents of goodwill towards each other after a separation who have amicably entered into an arrangement for a child's care only to have these private arrangements ignored when the Family Court makes orders. I support any measure that enhances the opportunity and likelihood for private and satisfactory agreements to be entered into. I endorse the comments of the Attorney-General who, in this House on December4 1996, said: Most people ... would prefer to deal with the whole process of separation and associated agreements over children, property and maintenance outside the court environment. 3864 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 15 May 1997 As with most members, my office receives case after case of constituents' concerns regarding child support and family law. I would just like to compliment all the staff in electorate offices from all sides of the House who have to deal with these cases. They are often very emotional, very highly charged and very difficult to deal with, and I extend congratulations and best wishes to the staff of the Child Support Agency who I suspect experience similar exchanges with people involved with the system. I want to point to a couple of examples. They highlight how the difficulty with the Child Support Agency is not typically skewed to one party, whether it is a matter of gender or custodial responsibilities. I have a constituent in Mornington who says it is all too easy for custodial parents to deny access, to make false accusations and have them acted upon through intervention orders. My constituent says there is no accountability and there is no deterrent against vexatious accusations that are costly to defend. He asserts that people can perjure themselves in the Family Court with apparent immunity. If you do not have the means to be able to take that matter further, then simply your access to your family members is curtailed because of those accusations. I have a female constituent in Karingal who has equally valid concerns. Her case is more complicated-it dates back almost a decade. Some ambiguous, badly drafted order from the Family Court has been interpreted by the Child Support Agency in such a way that she is now faced with having to refund over $3,000 of payments. I doubt, quite sincerely, that there has been an overpayment at all. It again shows the difficulty that many people experience with their interaction between the Family Court and the Child Support Agency. When we turned to the Family Court for assistance it was unable to access any records to shed any light on this case. Now this person has the difficulty of not only raising the children but also having the fear of the $3,000 hanging over them, which the Child Support Agency asserts-and I greatly doubt-needs to be refunded. The performance of the Child Support Agency has improved; I will not go over that, but it is an encouraging sign. This is the first step and there is more work to be done. I cannot see how people can expect to look for better behaviour from people who have gone through a difficult, emotional, and often very financially significant, experience such as a separation, if the system is not structured to encourage it. Far too many non-custodial parents come into my office, despairing at the difficulty they are having in re-establishing their lives. They have moved on to new relationships, they may even have new families, but because of some of the arrangements that are in place at present they find it very difficult to make a fresh start. They point to the way that entitlements and payments are calculated and that the circumstances of the other former partner are not taken into account in the same way in which their own are. The capacity of both former parents to contribute to the raising of the child does not seem to be equally investigated. At the end of the day that is the key; it is what is in the best interests of the child. Far too many people come into my office--excuse me if these terms are unparliamentaryand elect to take the 'stuff it' option. It is just too much for them. They wonder why they are working very hard to try and re-establish their lives and to make an appropriate contribution to the care of children from former relationships, only to find that they just cannot make ends meet. One partner explained to me how, upon separation, all the family furniture and the family house was provided to the parent who was going to continue the primary custodial duty. Thursday, 15 May 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 3865 That person tries to generate additional income through overtime so that the fruit boxes that are used as chairs in the lounge room can be replaced. But every time that extra effort is made, more of the resources go out of that person's pocket into the custodial person's pocket, in the non-custodial person's eyes without due cause. That person is saying, 'Hang on, the capacity to raise the children is something that we share; it's a responsibility we both have to bear, and as our lives move on, surely the circumstances of both of the original parents should playa larger role in calculating the child support payments.' I was somewhat disappointed that some very constructive measures that the subcommittee of government backbenchers put to the government were not incorporated in the budget. Some members on the other side might find that as an opportunity to have a go at us. But what I am suggesting to you is that work is going on; we understand that there are problems here. I also understand and accept the government's position that some well-intended, wellresearched ideas do need to be carefully looked at by government. But my message to the government is that we have not gone away, that those concerns remain, and our efforts to address them will continue. The great disappointment in the motion of the member for Werriwa and the contribution of the member for Hunter( Mr Fitzgibbon) is that they were simply carping away, saying there were issues that have not been resolvedthat is right; we understand that-just as the more contentious recommendations in the joint standing committee's report were left on the shelf by the previous Labor government. There is no gain in their contributions. There are families out there battling to make ends meet and that contribution is absolutely useless to the task that is before us. I encourage all those members opposite who have a contribution to make, to make it in a positive way. These are real people's lives and they are doing it pretty hard out there. In sticking with the theme of encouraging people to do the right thing, the member for Moreton( Mr Hardgrave) outlined, in his contribution, some of the ideas that we have been working through. These include: the way entitlements are calculated; how income is treated; what level of payment should be made once someone gets to 2Y2 times the average weekly earnings; how the custodial parents' circumstances change and how they should be addressed; the amount of exempt income so that people can get on with their lives; and the cost of raising children. If the task of raising the child is beyond the means of the two partners, we then have to look at whether our family payments system is supporting the raising of that child. Payments for child support should represent one of the first obligations all non-custodial parents have. If, after making those payments, their circumstances leave them in such an impoverished state that they are not able to carryon with their own lives, and perhaps the raising of other children that have come about from a subsequent relationship, we should take that into account. That costs money. We have to argue our case well and we are endeavouring to do that. I respect the government's role in making sure we are not doing anything too hasty that is not going to improve the situation. The issue about how reviews are conducted also troubles me. From the research I have done, the approach of the Child Support Agency seems to vary from state to state. I wonder whether it is not time to introduce the same sort of statement of principles you see operating in the Department of Veterans' Affairs so that all cases are dealt with equitably. In a state such as mine, a review application for child support payments far too often sees arrears wiped off. The fact is that it is money that the custodial parents would and should have had in their pockets to help with the raising of the child but it is wiped off. I understand that 3866 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 15 May 1997 there is a totally different practice in Queensland. That is unacceptable. They are all Australians. They are all facing similar dilemmas and they should all be treated reasonably equitably. I also believe there is an argument that says the question of visitation to children should be linked with people's performance in honouring their child support obligations. For people who cannot see their way clear to honour those obligations, I think there is an argument that says that the benefits and the joy of being involved with the development of your child should be curtailed. People say that that is harsh and unfair but, at the end of the day, it is about making sure the resources are available for the education, learning, training, growth, feeding, clothing and housing of the young child. If people cannot see their way clear to honour those responsibilities, I wonder whether they should be able to have as active a part in the rearing of that child. But there is a flip side to that for those non-custodial parents who are paying their way, and who find themselves in a situation where the custodial parent decides to move to Queensland with the child, which is often the case in the sunny Mornington Peninsula-sadly, some do not appreciate the beauty of our environment. I try to understand what it would be like if, heaven forbid, my relationship broke down and I was not able to have a role in the development of my child. I would consider that an enormous loss. I would want the opportunity to make a contribution in the development of something that I have played a part in creating so that needs to be weighed into the equation. If that means that the cost of gaining access to the child has to be somehow reflected in the payments, so be it. If that means that the non-custodial parent has to look at those visitation rights, and if it means that the Family Court and the Child Support Agency have to consider how they can more effectively interact so that the two sets of issues mesh more comfortably, then we should also be looking at that. I seek leave to continue my remarks later. Leave granted; debate adjourned.
